column2: Spanish: [asˈtuɾjas]; Asturian: Asturies [asˈtuɾjes; -ɾjɪs])
column3: officially the Principality of Asturias (Spanish: Principado de Asturias; Asturian: Principáu d'Asturies)
column4: is an autonomous community in north-west Spain. It is coextensive with the province of Asturias and contains some of the territory that was part of the larger Kingdom of Asturias in the Middle Ages. Divided into eight comarcas (counties)
column5: the autonomous community of Asturias is bordered by Cantabria to the east
column6: by León (Castile and León) to the south
column8: and by the Bay of Biscay (Cantabrian sea) to the north.

column1: Asturias is situated in a mountainous setting with vast greenery and lush vegetation
column2: making it part of Green Spain. The region has a maritime climate. It receives plenty of annual rainfall and little sunshine by Spanish standards and has very moderated seasons
column3: most often averaging in the lower 20s celsius. Heat waves are rare due to mountains blocking southerly winds. Winters are very mild for the latitude
column4: especially near sea level.

column1: The most important cities are the communal capital
column2: Oviedo (Uviéu)
column3: the seaport and largest city Gijón (Xixón)
column4: and the industrial town of Avilés. Other municipalities in Asturias include Cangas de Onís (Cangues d'Onís)
column5: Cangas del Narcea
column6: Gozón
column8: Langreo (Llangréu)
column17: and Villaviciosa (see also List of municipalities and comarcas in Asturias).

column1: Asturias is also home of the Princess of Asturias Awards.

column2: first by Homo erectus
column3: then by Neanderthals. Since the Lower Paleolithic era
column4: and during the Upper Paleolithic
column5: Asturias was characterized by cave paintings in the eastern part of the area. In the Mesolithic period
column6: a native culture developed
column8: and later
column9: with the introduction of the Bronze Age
column10: megaliths and tumuli were constructed. In the Iron Age
column11: the territory came under the cultural influence of the Celts; the local Celtic peoples
column13: were composed of tribes such as the Luggones
column16: who populated the entire area with castros (fortified hill-towns). Today the Astur Celtic influence persists in place names
column17: such as those of rivers and mountains.

column1: With the conquest of Asturias by the Romans under Augustus (29–19 BC)
column2: the region entered into recorded history. The Astures were subdued by the Romans but were never fully conquered. After several centuries without foreign presence
column3: they enjoyed a brief revival during the Germanic invasions of the late 4th century AD
column4: resisting Suevi and Visigoth raids throughout the 5th Century AD
column5: ending with the Moorish invasion of Spain. However
column6: as it had been for the Romans and Visigoths
column7: the Moors did not find mountainous territory easy to conquer
column8: and the lands along Spain's northern coast never fully became part of Islamic Spain. Rather
column9: with the beginning of the Moorish conquest in the 8th century
column10: this region became a refuge for Christian nobles
column12: a de facto independent kingdom was established
column14: which was to become the cradle of the incipient Reconquista (Reconquest).

column2: the Kingdom of Asturias gave way to the Kingdom of León
column3: and during the Middle Ages the geographic isolation of the territory made historical references scarce. Through the rebellion of Henry II of Castile in the 14th century
column4: the Principality of Asturias was established. The most famous proponents of independence were Gonzalo Peláez and Queen Urraca
column5: who
column6: while achieving significant victories
column7: were ultimately defeated by Castilian troops. After its integration into the Kingdom of Spain
column8: Asturias provided the Spanish court with high-ranking aristocrats and played an important role in the colonisation of America. Since 1388
column9: the heir to the Castilian (later Spanish) throne has been styled Prince of Asturias. In the 16th century
column12: and within another century that number would double due to the arrival of American corn.

column2: Asturias was one of the centres of the Spanish Enlightenment. The renowned Galician thinker Benito de Feijóo settled in the Benedictine Monastery of San Vicente de Oviedo. Gaspar Melchor de Jovellanos
column3: a polymath and prominent reformer and politician of the late 18th century
column4: was born in the seaside town of Gijón.

column2: Asturias was the first Spanish province to rise up against the French following the abdication of King Ferdinand VII on 10 May 1808. Riots began in Oviedo and on 25 May the local government formally declared war on Napoleon with 18
column3: 000 men called to arms to resist invasion.The Industrial Revolution came to Asturias after 1830 with the discovery and systematic exploitation of coal mines and iron factories at the mining basins of Nalón and Caudal. At the same time
column4: there was significant migration to the Americas (especially Argentina
column5: Uruguay
column6: Puerto Rico
column7: Cuba and Mexico); those who succeeded overseas often returned to their native land much wealthier. These entrepreneurs were known collectively as 'Indianos'
column8: for having visited and made their fortunes in the West Indies and beyond. The heritage of these wealthy families can still be seen in Asturias today: many large 'modernista' villas are dotted across the region
column9: as well as cultural institutions such as free schools and public libraries.

column1: Asturias played an important part in the events that led up to the Spanish Civil War. In October 1934 Asturian miners and other workers staged an armed uprising  (see Revolution of Asturias) to oppose the coming to power of the right-wing CEDA party
column2: which had obtained three ministerial posts in the centralist government of the Second Spanish Republic. For a month
column3: a Popular Front Committee exercised control in southern Asturias
column4: while local workers committees sprang up elsewhere in the region. A war committee dominated by anarcho-syndicalist supporters took power in Oviedo . Troops under the command of a then unknown general named Francisco Franco Bahamonde were brought from Spanish Morocco to suppress the revolt. Franco applied tactics normally reserved for overseas colonies
column5: using troops of the Spanish Legion and Moroccan troops: ferocious oppression followed.

column2: Asturias remained loyal to the republican government during the Spanish Civil War
column3: and was the scene of an extraordinary defence in extreme terrain
column4: the Battle of El Mazuco. With Franco eventually gaining control of all Spain
column5: Asturias — traditionally linked to the Spanish Crown — was known merely as the "Province of Oviedo" from 1939 until Franco's death in 1975. The province's name was restored fully after the return of democracy to Spain
column6: in 1977. In the 50s and 60s the industrial progress of Asturias continued with the constitution of national enterprises like Ensidesa and Hunosa
column7: but the 80s was the decade of a dramatic industrial restructuring.

column2: Asturias became an autonomous community within the decentralised territorial structure established by the Constitution of 1978. Rafael Luis Fernández Álvarez
column3: who had previously served as the President of the Regional Council since 1978
column4: became the first President of the Principality of Asturias
column5: upon the adoption of autonomy. The Asturian regional government holds comprehensive competencies in important areas such as health
column6: education and protection of the environment. The current president
column8: Adrián Barbón (PSOE).

column1: Asturias is organised territorially into 78 municipalities
column2: further subdivided into parishes.

column1: Asturias is also divided into eight comarcas
column2: which are not administrative divisions. They are only used as a system to homogenize the statistical data made by the Principality.

column1: The parroquia or parish is the subdivision of the Asturian municipalities. Currently
column2: there are 857 parishes integrating the 78 municipalities in the region
column3: and they usually coincide with the ecclesiastic divisions.

column1: The Cantabrian Mountains (Cordillera Cantábrica) form Asturias's natural border with the province of León to the south. In the eastern range
column2: the Picos de Europa National Park contains the highest and arguably most spectacular mountains
column3: rising to 2
column4: 648 metres (8
column5: 688 ft) at the Torrecerredo peak. Other notable features of this predominantly limestone range are the Parque Natural de Redes in the central east
column6: the central Ubiñas south of Oviedo
column7: and the Parque Natural de Somiedo in the west. The Cantabrian mountains offer opportunities for activities such as climbing
column8: walking
column10: and extend some 200 kilometres (120 mi) in total
column11: as far as Galicia province to the west of Asturias and Cantabria province to the east. Similar opportunities are available for the traveler of Asturias interested in Caldoveiro Peak.

column2: with hundreds of beaches
column3: coves and natural sea caves. Notable examples include the Playa del Silencio (Beach of Silence) near the fishing village of Cudillero (west of Gijón)
column4: as well as the many beaches surrounding the summer resort of Llanes
column5: such as the Barro

column1: The key features of Asturian geography are its rugged coastal cliffs and the mountainous interior.
The climate of Asturias is heavily marked by the gulf stream. Falling within the Cantabrian belt known as Green Spain it has high precipitations all year round. Summers are mild and
column2: on the coast
column3: winters also have relatively benign temperatures
column4: rarely including frost. The cold is especially felt in the mountains
column5: where snow is present from October till May. Both rain and snow are regular weather features of Asturian winters. In coastal or near-coastal areas
column6: daytime high temperatures generally average around 12 °C (54 °F) – 13 °C (55 °F) during winter and 22 °C (72 °F) – 23 °C (73 °F) in summer.

column1: This part of Spain is one of the most well conserved in the entire country
column2: and full of vegetation and wild spaces. It holds two of the most important natural parks in Spain
column3: and is very renowned for the Picos de Europa and Somiedo areas.

column1: The Gijón area was marked and singled out as one of the pollution hotspots in Western Europe in a 2015 report from the International Institute for Applied Science Systems
column2: where predictions for 2030 conditions were made. Gijón was marked much higher than any other Spanish metro area
column3: in spite of the much larger populations in cities such as Madrid and Barcelona. This was attributed to heavy industrial activities. Since outdoor air pollution is a major cause of premature death in Europe
column4: the excessive pollution is a major concern for Asturias. The majority of Asturias population live within a 25 kilometres (16 mi) range from the port of Gijón
column5: so pollution would be likely to heavily affect the population.

column1: A Spanish government study conducted in 2010 regarding life expectancy in relative communities
column2: Asturias was ranked lowest (tied with Andalucia) for male life expectancy with 76.7 years from 2007 readings. However
column3: female life expectancy was 84 years and normal among autonomous communities. However
column4: even the male life expectancy is only just below Western European standards
column5: and exaggerated by the high Spanish life expectancy. Considering that many Asturians live in relatively close proximity to Gijón's heavily industrial areas
column6: these figures for especially female relative health still contribute to a position that Gijón is a safe location to live. The numbers for "disability-free" life expectancy has risen significantly both for males and females in the area since 1986
column7: according to the report.Update: the coal fired electric generating plant
column8: Aboño
column9: completed a Spanish government/EU demand to install equipment to drastically reduce its emissions. Also
column10: the other two major polluters - Arcelor Gijón and Arcelor Avilés - have announced an investment of 100 million euros to do the same. These factories have been a major cause of the area's high airborne pollution.

column1: The organisation and political structure of Asturias is governed by the Statute of Autonomy of the Principality of Asturias
column2: in force since 30 January 1982. According to the Statute
column3: the institutional bodies of the Principality of Asturias are three: the Council of Government
column4: the General Junta and President. The form of government of the Principality is Parliament: The General Junta is the legislature to choose
column5: on behalf of the Asturian people
column6: the President of the Principality of Asturias. The President is also the one of the Council of Government
column8: and politically answerable to the General Junta.

column1: The functions of the General Junta are the approval of budgets
column2: and the direction and control of the action of the Council of Government. It is composed of 45 deputies
column3: elected for four years through theuniversal suffrage within a system proportional representation that the allocation of deputies is based on D'Hondt method.

column2: the backbone of the Asturian economy was agriculture and fishing. Milk production and its derivatives was also traditional
column3: but its big development was a byproduct of the economic expansion of the late 1960s. Nowadays
column4: products from the dairy cooperative Central Lechera Asturiana are being commercialised all over Spain.

column1: The main regional industry in modern times
column2: however
column3: was coal mining and steel production: in the times of Francisco Franco's dictatorship
column4: it was the centre of Spain's steel industry. The then state-owned ENSIDESA steel company is now part of the privatised Aceralia
column5: now part of the ArcelorMittal Group. The industry created many jobs
column6: which resulted in significant migration from other regions in Spain
column8: Andalusia and Castile and León.

column1: The steel industry is now in decline when measured in terms of number of jobs provided
column2: as is the mining. The reasons for the latter are mainly the high costs of production to extract the coal compared to other regions. Regional economic growth is below the broader Spanish rate
column3: though in recent years growth in service industries has helped reduce Asturias's high rate of unemployment. Large out-of-town retail parks have opened near the region's largest cities (Gijón and Oviedo)
column4: whilst the ever-present Spanish construction industry appears to continue to thrive.

column1: Asturias has benefited extensively since 1986 from European Union investment in roads and other essential infrastructure
column2: though there has also been some controversy regarding how these funds are spent
column3: for example
column4: on miners' pensions.

column1: The Gross domestic product (GDP) of the autonomous community was 23.3 billion euros in 2018
column2: accounting for 1.9% of Spanish economic output. GDP per capita adjusted for purchasing power was 24
column3: 400 euros or 81% of the EU27 average in the same year. The GDP per employee was 98% of the EU average. This makes the region the 10th richest in Spain
column4: a big decrease from the 1970s/1980s - the heyday of the Spanish mining industry
column5: when Asturias was commonly regarded as one of the most prosperous regions in Southern Europe. Asturias has been growing below the Spanish national average since the decline of the mining industry
column6: and grew just 0.82% in 2008
column7: the lowest of all regions in Spain. On the plus side
column8: unemployment in Asturias is below the average of Spain; it stood at 13.7% in 2017.

column1: The shrine to the Virgin of Covadonga and the mountain lakes (Los Lagos)

The Reconquista and eventual unification of all Spain is therefore said to have started in this very location.The paleolithic art in the caves of Asturias is declared World Heritage Site with the Paleolithic Art of Northern Spain.

Asturias has a rich artistic legacy that emphasizes Romanesque (Asturias Arts) indigenous architecture with monuments like Santa María del Naranco
column2: Santa Cristina de Lena and San Miguel de Lillo. These monuments have a Ramirense Romanesque style (due to Ramiro I) or San Julián de los Prados
column3: known as Santullano (Oviedo) of the Alfonsino pre-Romanesque style (due to Alfonso II)
column4: which are all in Oviedo. Other examples of architecture are Villaviciosa's church
column5: San Salvador de Valdediós (commonly known by the Asturians as "Conventín")
column6: and the church of San Salvador de Priesca. Another example is Cabranes' San Julian de Viñón.

column1: The Romanesque style is very present
column2: since all Asturias is crossed by one of the Camino de Santiago routes
column3: which highlights the Monastery of San Pedro de Villanueva (near Cangas de Onis)
column4: the churches of San Esteban de Aramil (Siero)
column5: San Juan de Amandi (Villaviciosa) and Santa María de Junco (Ribadesella).

column1: The Gothic style is not as abundant
column2: but there are good examples of this style
column3: such as the Cathedral of San Salvador in Oviedo.

column1: The Baroque style is more present by means of palace architecture
column2: with such notable examples as the Palace of Camposagrado and Velarde - the latter seat of Museum of Fine Arts of Asturias. The Baroque style stands out in public civil engineering and bridge tolls (Olloniego); the milestones
column3: the chairs or seats present along the road to Madrid and the resort of Caldas de Priorio (Oviedo) building.

the traditional granaries in Asturias
column3: called hórreos

column5: its basic characteristic being its mobility: it can be easily dismounted and transported to another location. The Panera is the evolution of the hórreo

column1: Some of the most famous festivals in Asturias are from the small town of Llanes. These festivals celebrate the important saints and the Virgin Mary adored by the town. The associations that prepare the festivals have a rivalry between them and each year they try to outdo each other with more impressive shows. The three most important are the festival of San Roque (St. Roque) held on the 16th of August
column2: the festival of Nuestra Señora Virgen de La Guia (Our Lady
column3: Virgin Mary
column4: the Guide) held on the 8th of September
column5: and the festival of Santa Maria Magdalena (St. Mary Magdalene) held on the 22nd of July. The Magdalena is well known for its impressive march of logs where boys as young as 3 and men carry logs through the town until they reach the end point and start a large bonfire.

column1: While Asturias is especially known for its seafood

column1: Apple groves foster the production of the region's traditional alcoholic drink
column2: a natural cider (sidra). Since it is natural and bottled without gas
column3: it produces a weak carbonation
column4: and when Asturian cider is served
column5: it is poured in a particular way
column6: el escanciado: the bottle is held above the head allowing for a long vertical pour
column7: causing the cider to be aerated as it splashes into the glass below. After drinking most of the content
column8: it is customary to splash a little out onto the ground
column9: as a way to clean the glass of any lees for the next serving. Traditionally
column10: the same glass is refilled and passed around
column11: with everyone drinking from it in turn.

column2: especially Cabrales
column3: are also eaten throughout Spain and beyond; Asturias is often called "the land of cheeses" (el país de los quesos).

The music of Asturias is varied. The most characteristic instrument in traditional music is the Asturian bagpipe
column2: or Gaita asturiana
column3: which has a single drone
column4: in common with the traditional bagpipes of other Celtic nations such as Wales and Ireland. The bagpipe is often accompanied by the hand drum
column5: whistles and accordion.

column2: there has been a resurgence of interest in traditional folk music
column3: and several music ensembles have gained regional and international recognition for their ethnomusicological study and presentation of indigenous Asturian music.  Notable examples include traditional pipers such as Xuacu Amieva and Tejedor and fusionist José Ángel Hevia (whose music video provides views of both the gaita and the Asturian landscape)
column4: and the groups Llan de Cubel
column5: Xera
column6: Nuberu and Felpeyu. Additionally
column8: ska and heavy metal groups have also found relative success within Asturias
column9: many of which incorporate elements of traditional Asturian music into their sound.

column1: === Orquesta Sinfónica del Principado de Asturias ===
The Orquesta Sinfónica del Principado de Asturias is the premier orchestra in the Principality of Asturias. It is based in the Auditorio Príncipe Felipe in Oviedo
column2: but also performs in the main concert venues in Gijón and Avilés. Rossen Milanov is the Music Director.

column4: which quotes liberally from Asturian musical heritage.
